quiz.title: Unit 12: AP Microeconomics (Quiz 12)
quiz.subtitle: Monopoly, Price Discrimination, Monopolistic Competition
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Marginal Revenue, Efficiency, Price Discrimination, Long-Run Equilibrium

questions.question: When a monopoly firm is operating in a range of output where total revenue is rising as output rises, then marginal revenue:
options: Is also rising.
Is constant.
Is falling but is greater than zero.
Is falling but is less than zero.
questions.explanation: If TR is increasing, MR > 0. For a downward-sloping demand curve, MR is positive but decreasing until it becomes negative when TR starts falling.

questions.question: An indication of the technological inefficiency of the monopolist, when compared to the perfect competitor, is that:
options: The monopolist's price is set above the marginal cost of the good.
The demand curve facing the monopolist is downward sloping.
In the long-run, a monopolist is not forced to produce at the minimum point of the average total cost curve.
A monopolist earns more economic profit in the long-run than does the competitive firm.
The monopolist has no competition to force him to produce where MC = MR.
questions.explanation: Perfect competitors produce at min ATC in LR; monopolists do not necessarily do so, leading to excess capacity or higher ATC → technological inefficiency.

questions.question: Price discrimination:
options: Tends to decrease the allocative inefficiency of a monopolist.
Will provide more total revenue to the firm than the profit-maximizing price the monopolist would set in the absence of such discrimination.
Generally results in greater output than under a single price monopoly.
When it is perfect, causes the monopolist to produce where marginal social cost is just equal to marginal social benefit.
All of the above.
questions.explanation: Price discrimination can increase output, reduce deadweight loss, raise revenue, and under perfect (first-degree) discrimination, output expands to P = MC, achieving allocative efficiency.

questions.question: Although a monopolistically competitive firm in long-run equilibrium is producing output at an average total cost higher than the minimum, economists are not greatly concerned about this inefficiency because:
options: Additional firms may enter the industry and force price down.
Consumers gain satisfaction from having a wide variety of products available.
Consumers would unquestionably benefit from having fewer products produced more cheaply.
Advertising may allow a firm to expand output.
Firms are making zero economic profit.
questions.explanation: The higher ATC reflects product differentiation and variety, which consumers value. The trade-off between variety and productive efficiency is often considered acceptable.

questions.question: The demand curve that confronts a monopolistically competitive firms is:
options: Less elastic than the demand curve that confronts the industry.
Perfectly inelastic because of numerous substitutes for the firm's product.
Less elastic than the demand curve facing a perfectly competitive firm.
Horizontal, showing that MR = P.
Perfectly elastic in the long-run, driving economic profits to zero.
questions.explanation: Monopolistically competitive firms face downward-sloping demand curves, which are less elastic (steeper) than the perfectly elastic demand of perfect competitors, but more elastic than a monopolist's demand.

questions.question: Historically, coal miners had a very high risk of developing various lung diseases, due in part to lack of ventilation. Engineering advancements allowed better ventilation in mines, eliminating some of this risk. Which is the most likely impact of these engineering advancements upon the supply and demand for labor in the mining industry?
options: Demand curve will shift left, supply curve will shift right
Demand curve will shift left, supply curve will shift left
Demand curve will shift right, supply curve will shift right
Demand curve will not shift, supply curve will shift left
Demand curve will not shift, supply curve will shift right
questions.explanation: Safer working conditions make mining jobs more attractive, increasing labor supply (right shift). Demand for labor depends on productivity and output demand, not directly on safety, so likely unchanged.

questions.question: If the demand for health care is very inelastic, an increase in the price of health care will
options: increase the total revenue of health care providers
decrease the total revenue of health care providers
decrease the total consumer expenditures on health care
cause the demand for health care to increase
have no effect on the total revenue of health care providers
questions.explanation: Inelastic demand: price increase → small drop in quantity → total revenue rises.

questions.question: If only one supplier in a perfectly competitive market received a per-unit subsidy this year, how will this subsidy impact the firm's price and output in the short run?
options: price will increase; output will increase
price will not change; output will increase
price will decrease; output will increase
price will not change; output will decrease
price will decrease; output will decrease
questions.explanation: Firm is price taker; market price unchanged. Subsidy reduces MC, so firm expands output where P = new lower MC.

questions.question: Why does the marginal cost of producing cookies eventually increases in the short run?
options: economies of scale
diseconomies of scale
increasing fixed costs
diminishing marginal product
increasing marginal product
questions.explanation: Diminishing marginal product of variable inputs (like labor) causes MC to rise as output expands in short run (fixed capital).

questions.question: Which of the following is always true about the relationship between a firm's ATC and MC curves in the short run?
options: the ATC curve intersects the MC curve at the minimum point of the MC curve
the MC curve intersects the ATC curve at the minimum point of the ATC curve
the MC curve intersects the ATC curve at the maximum point of the ATC curve
ATC and MC are always equal
ATC and MC are never equal
questions.explanation: MC always intersects ATC at its minimum point. If MC < ATC, ATC falls; if MC > ATC, ATC rises.

questions.question: Assuming all of a firm's cost are explicit, the output level where accounting profit is maximized will always be where
options: Total revenue equals total implicit costs
price equals average total cost
price equals marginal cost
the difference between marginal revenue and marginal cost is maximized
marginal cost equals marginal revenue
questions.explanation: Profit maximization (including accounting profit) occurs where MR = MC. In perfect competition, P = MR, so P = MC.

questions.question: Which of the following is least likely to increase economic profit in any given market?
options: Effective price discrimination
A few firms consolidating market shares
A government subsidy
An effective price floor
Low barriers to entry
questions.explanation: Low barriers to entry encourage new firms, increase competition, drive down prices, and reduce economic profit in long run.

questions.question: Which of the following will most likely occur if a perfectly competitive market is replaced by a single-price monopolist?
options: The deadweight loss will increase
Profit-maximizing output will increase
Price will decrease
Economic profit will decrease
The firm's total revenue will increase
questions.explanation: Monopoly restricts output below competitive level, raising price and creating deadweight loss (reduction in total surplus).

questions.question: Given the information in the payoff matrix, it can be concluded that
options: neither E Soda nor R Soda has a dominant strategy
E Soda has a dominant strategy but R Soda does not
R Soda has a dominant strategy but E Soda does not
both firms will choose the high-price strategy
both firms will choose the low-price strategy
questions.explanation: A dominant strategy gives a higher payoff regardless of opponent's choice. For E Soda: If R picks Low, E earns 25 (Low) > 15 (High). If R picks High, E earns 90 (Low) > 75 (High) → Low is dominant. For R Soda: If E picks Low, R earns 25 (Low) > 15 (High). If E picks High, R earns 90 (Low) > 75 (High) → Low is dominant. Both have dominant strategy Low → equilibrium (Low, Low).

questions.question: Based on the table for a perfectly competitive firm above, if the wage rate for labor is $15, how many units of labor should the firm hire?
questions.explanation: A firm hires labor until MRP = wage (or MRP ≥ wage). MRP: 1st = $40, 2nd = $28, 3rd = $24, 4th = $16, 5th = $12. Wage = $15. Hire 4 workers because 4th worker’s MRP ($16) > wage ($15), but 5th worker’s MRP ($12) < wage → stop at 4.

questions.question: A monopolistically competitive firm is currently in long-run equilibrium. If the output of the firm is 50 units and the price the firm receives for each product is $10, what is the total cost for this firm?
options: There is not enough information given to determine average total cost.
questions.explanation: Long-run monopolistic competitive equilibrium: P = ATC, zero economic profit. Total revenue = $10 × 50 = $500. Since P = ATC, total cost = total revenue = $500.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of monopoly, price discrimination, and monopolistic competition dynamics.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review MR behavior, efficiency trade-offs, and long-run equilibrium differences.
scoreMessages.50: Basic understanding; focus on monopolist vs. competitive firm behavior and variety vs. efficiency.
scoreMessages.0: Review: MR under downward-sloping demand, price discrimination effects, and monopolistic competition characteristics.
